@cradal thanks for the help reviewing internal code but this ticket was more for handling code that currently is NOT part of the API or SPI.  This was to deal with code that should either be part of the public API/SPI or removed from configuration properties, like I did with the MemoryManger.  We had a property for users to write their own MemoryManager but the interface used server components that were not user friendly.  

I think I will have to do the same with the interfaces in org.apache.accumulo.server.security.handler classes (Authenticator, Authorizor, PermissionHandler).  These interfaces are called when Accumulo executes important security procedures (like creating users, initializing a system) but they really only work internally.  It feels like they were added to add the ability for Kerberos to work with the default Zookeeper behavior.  I don't know how we can rework these interfaces to extend this behavior without completely rewriting the interfaces to work in the SPI.

@keith-turner @ctubbsii I came up with one solution in #1721 to solve the issues with the security interfaces.  It will break if a user actually has a custom security implementation so its not perfect but we maintain the Kerberos functionality and get those interfaces out of the properties.  It does that also without having to rewrite everything to work in the SPI.

> Until that comprehensive work is done, I think these should remain non-public API, and left as an advanced / marginally supported feature through the "internal" APIs. If it's "easy" to make the existing interfaces themselves public API / SPI, without exposing additional internal types, I'd be okay with that change also.

I made attempts at trying to modify them to fit our API or SPI.  The SPI may be more feasible but the main problem is their implementation relies heavily on access to internal ZooKeeper objects.  Most of the work the classes are doing is just interacting with zookeeper.  The Kerberos impl still uses the ZK impl but with added checks.  So I don't think there is an "easy" approach.

> @milleruntime These interfaces were added in ACCUMULO-259 (I still have the JIRA issue memorized, because it was quite an ordeal at the time) to be pluggable. It was not merely added to support Kerberos/SASL authentication as an alternative. Rather, it was intended to be completely pluggable... so you could swap in an LDAP implementation, for example.

Do you remember if there was an actual customer need to have pluggable LDAP or something other than Kerberos?  Reading the JIRA tickets, it seems this was just a developer idea.  https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ACCUMULO-259.

> Do you remember if there was an actual customer need to have pluggable LDAP or something other than Kerberos? Reading the JIRA tickets, it seems this was just a developer idea. https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ACCUMULO-259.

I have been informed in the past that people were doing this. However, I do not know if they still are. Either way, it is a capability I'd like to preserve, and improve upon, even if the API isn't stable. If we want to mark it as `@Experimental` in the interim, due to its limited support as non-public API, I think that might be our best option.

> Is there a way to limit the 2x zookeeper timeout period? As it stands, most of the tests will timeout before the zookeeper timeout is reached.

@Manno15 Not a good way for an existing (standalone) cluster, no. Even if there was an easy way to time out before that, we would probably end up with false negatives (we conclude that ZK is not running when it really is, but we didn't give it enough time to connect). If tests are set to time out before 2x ZK timeout, I'm surprised we don't have more flaky tests. I would consider 2x ZK timeout to be the minimum time we should wait for a test to finish (but it's not worth changing it if they are working today).
It's possible there's not a good way to fail fast, and there's nothing to be done for this ticket.

You should be able to set the ```.zkTimeout()``` [here](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/3fd5cad92f9b63ac19e4466f3f2d5237b905262c/test/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/harness/conf/StandaloneAccumuloClusterConfiguration.java#L110) on the ClientInfo.  I am not sure if that will get overridden by the framework though.  If that works, we could add the timeout as another property in the standalone config file.

> You should be able to set the `.zkTimeout()` [here](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/3fd5cad92f9b63ac19e4466f3f2d5237b905262c/test/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/harness/conf/StandaloneAccumuloClusterConfiguration.java#L110) on the ClientInfo. I am not sure if that will get overridden by the framework though. If that works, we could add the timeout as another property in the standalone config file.

Based on [the docs](https://zookeeper.apache.org/doc/r3.4.14/zookeeperAdmin.html), the minimum session timeout that the client is able to negotiate is determined by a server-side setting, and defaults to 2x the `tickTime`. So, setting something in our client lower than that would be limited by the minimum. This is what I thought @Manno15  was referring to. However, reading back, I'm not sure if he was referring to that when he said "2x zookeeper timeout period" or something else.

Many client operations may just wait for the service to come online, but perhaps not all. It won't fail immediately per se. It fails when zookeeper times out. Which, if users are running a standalone IT and add in a timeout factor, will faill faster than the test itself. The limitations are that it checks for a zookeeper connection before trying to do any client activity. So if zookeeper isn't running then it will always hang trying to connect to it. Ideally, I would be able to check for manager status or something like that before trying to connect to zookeeper so I could fail quicker but I don't know if that is possible.

@milleruntime I ran the ReadWriteIT in the debugger. It is hitting my checkConnection() function and failing but it's doing each test separately which is an issue. Even with a runtime exception, it will still go to the next test in the IT instead of failing completely. I assume this is why it looks like it is hanging for 20 minutes but it is just going through each test individually. Each test will have a timeout of 6 minutes normally, not the entire IT.

This is intended. The `integration-test` phase executes all the tests and gathers the results. The `verify` phase is the phase where the results are inspected and the `maven-failsafe-plugin` kills the build or not. I don't think we'd even want to work around this, even if we could.

The only other thing I could think to do is to add a `maven-exec-plugin` task to check for the running cluster *before* the `maven-failsafe-plugin` ran, but I really don't think that's worth it. Whether you decide to merge this or close without merging, I think it's probably best to close the original issue, either way.

Hi @wangxiaofan777 

Accumulo 2.0.0 was released with support for 3.4.14. However, starting with ZooKeeper 3.5, they moved their jars into a `lib/` subdirectory. So, you will need to modify the instructions slightly to add `$ZOOKEEPER_HOME/lib/*` to your `CLASSPATH` variable in your `accumulo-env.sh` .

I hope that helps.

However, a `Stream` would only give us a stream of `Entry<Key, Value>`, and a `forEach` for that wouldn't be as useful as one with a `BiConsumer`, like the `Map` interface provides. However, this can be done independently without worrying about all the messiness that comes with decisions about streams (like what to do with `.stream().parallel()`).
